So, what are some of the expectations of the role?
Well, it's a very archaic, old-fashioned title, right? You know, Jackie Kennedy said that she never wanted to be called First Lady. It sounded like a saddle horse.

It's very arcane because people don't understand it. And even years of studying it myself, I found it to be completely dependent on the person who has the position.

And do what they want with it. Because as Rosalind Carter said, no matter what, you're going to be criticized.
And, you know, there's a lot of sexism, obviously, and in the world still.

Yeah, because Michelle Obama, you know, she, it was the school lunch initiative, you know, healthier nutrition.

Like, how much of those expectations are part of the role?

You have to have something that you really give a lot of extra give a damn about and you have to roll out a plan about that to the American people over the next four years and hopefully with no scandals messing it up in the meantime.

When we were developing the piece chronologically, when we hit like Eleanor Roosevelt, like that was a big one that like, there was so much to unpack.

From the earliest days, America's first ladies were referred to as Lady Presidentress or Republican Queen.
